subject: accountancy
title: Basic Accounting Terms
notes: Complete real MCQ bank (100 questions) for Basic Accounting Terms for JKSSB Finance Accounts Assistant.
Includes basic, moderate and advanced questions with explanations.

questions.text: Which of the following is an asset?
questions.explanation: Debtors represent receivables and are treated as assets of the business.

questions.text: Which of the following is a liability?
questions.explanation: Bills Payable is an obligation to pay in future, hence a liability.

questions.text: Capital represents:
questions.explanation: Capital is the owner’s investment or equity in the business.

questions.text: Goods purchased for resale are known as:
questions.explanation: Goods purchased with the intention of resale are called purchases.

questions.text: Cash withdrawn by owner for personal use is called:
questions.explanation: When the owner withdraws cash or goods for personal use, it is called drawings.

questions.text: An increase in assets generally indicates:
questions.explanation: Increase in assets normally strengthens the financial position or may result from profits.

questions.text: Salary outstanding is classified as:
questions.explanation: Outstanding salary is a payment due to employees, so it is a liability.

questions.text: Prepaid insurance is a:
questions.explanation: Prepaid insurance is a payment made in advance and gives future benefit, hence an asset.

questions.text: Wages paid for installation of machinery is treated as:
questions.explanation: Cost of installation is added to machinery cost, hence capital expenditure.

questions.text: Rent received is classified as:
questions.explanation: Rent received is an income for the business.

questions.text: Trade discount is:

options.a: Recorded in the books of accounts
options.b: Not recorded in the books of accounts
options.c: Recorded in the cash book only

questions.explanation: Trade discount is deducted before recording the transaction; it is not recorded separately.

questions.text: Cash discount is:

options.b: Recorded in the books as discount allowed/received

questions.explanation: Cash discount is allowed/received on prompt payment and is recorded as an expense or income.

questions.text: Goods sold on credit increases:
questions.explanation: On credit sales, the amount becomes receivable from customers, increasing debtors.

questions.text: Something of value owned by a business is called:
questions.explanation: Anything owned by the business which has value is an asset.

questions.text: Loss of value of an asset due to wear and tear is called:
questions.explanation: Reduction in value of tangible fixed assets due to use is called depreciation.

questions.text: Cash received from sale of old furniture is usually treated as:
questions.explanation: Sale of fixed asset is a capital transaction, so receipt is capital in nature.

questions.text: Commission received is shown as:

options.a: Expense in profit and loss account
options.b: Income in profit and loss account

questions.explanation: Commission received is an income and appears on credit side of profit and loss account.

questions.text: Assets – Liabilities = ?
questions.explanation: According to the accounting equation, Capital = Assets – Liabilities.

questions.text: Credit purchases increase:
questions.explanation: On credit purchases, the amount is payable to suppliers, increasing creditors.

questions.text: Fixed assets are held for:
questions.explanation: Fixed assets are acquired for long-term use in business, not for resale.

questions.text: Unearned income is treated as:
questions.explanation: Unearned income (income received in advance) is a liability until service is rendered.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an asset?
questions.explanation: Outstanding rent is an amount payable, so it is a liability, not an asset.

questions.text: Goodwill is classified as:
questions.explanation: Goodwill has no physical form but has value, hence an intangible asset.

questions.text: Carriage inward is:
questions.explanation: Carriage inward is directly related to bringing goods to business and is a direct expense.

questions.text: Carriage outward is generally treated as:
questions.explanation: Carriage outward relates to delivery to customers and is an indirect selling expense.

questions.text: Outstanding expenses appear under which head in the balance sheet?
questions.explanation: Outstanding expenses are obligations to pay in future, hence current liabilities.

questions.text: Which transaction increases both an asset and a liability?
questions.explanation: Credit purchase increases stock (asset) and creditors (liability).

questions.text: Which of the following decreases capital?
questions.explanation: Drawings reduce the owner’s equity or capital in the business.

questions.text: Which one is a nominal account?
questions.explanation: Rent is an expense and is classified as a nominal account.
